column1: According to the MU-Varna stage precision logic, at which precise phase does the breakdown of the nuclear envelope occur?
column8:
Correct: B — Prometaphase
Why: Phosphorylation of lamins leads to the disassembly of the nuclear envelope specifically during this transitional phase.
High-yield:
  • Core mechanism: CDK1–Cyclin B phosphorylates lamins and nuclear pore proteins → lamina disassembly + nuclear envelope breakdown (NEBD).
  • Exam anchor: NEBD defines prometaphase (transition after prophase).
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Anaphase
  • C — Metaphase
  • D — Prophase: While chromatin begins to condense here, the envelope breakdown is a more specific later event.

column1: Which component of the nuclear envelope is continuous with the Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum (RER) and can bind ribosomes?
column8:
Correct: B — Outer nuclear membrane
Why: The outer membrane is structurally and functionally continuous with the RER.
High-yield:
  • Outer nuclear membrane is continuous with RER and can carry ribosomes.
  • Inner nuclear membrane anchors lamina and peripheral heterochromatin.
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Inner nuclear membrane
  • C — Nuclear lamina: This is an internal meshwork of intermediate filaments, not a membrane.
  • D — Perinuclear space

column1: A researcher observes dark-staining, condensed DNA anchored to the nuclear lamina. Which of the following best describes this material?
column8:
Correct: C — Heterochromatin
Why: Heterochromatin is transcriptionally inactive, highly condensed, and often peripheral.
High-yield:
  • Heterochromatin: condensed, transcriptionally inactive, typically peripheral, attached to the nuclear lamina.
  • Euchromatin: open, transcriptionally active, lightly stained.
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Euchromatin
  • B — Nucleolus
  • D — Barr body

column1: What is the basic structural unit of chromatin, consisting of DNA wrapped around a histone octamer?
column8:
Correct: A — Nucleosome
Why: A nucleosome consists of roughly 150 bp of DNA wrapped around histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Chromatid
  • C — Nucleoporin
  • D — Centrosome

column1: The nucleolus is highly prominent in cells with high protein synthesis. What is its primary TEM-visible granular component responsible for?
column8:
Correct: C — Ribosomal subunit assembly
Why: The granular component is where the final assembly of ribosomal subunits takes place.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — rRNA gene storage
  • B — Histone synthesis
  • D — mRNA transcription

column1: In which phase of the cell cycle is the DNA content doubled alongside the synthesis of histones?
column8:
Correct: A — S phase
Why: The S (synthesis) phase is specifically for DNA replication and histone production.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — M phase
  • C — G1 phase: This is the longest phase focused on growth and preparation.
  • D — G2 phase

column1: Which of the following events is unique to Prophase I of meiosis compared to mitotic prophase?
column8:
Correct: A — Synapsis of homologous chromosomes
Why: Meiosis involves the pairing of homologous chromosomes to allow for genetic recombination.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Disappearance of the nucleolus
  • C — Migration of centrosomes
  • D — Condensation of chromatin

column1: Apoptosis is often distinguished from necrosis by several key features. Which of the following is characteristic ONLY of apoptosis?
column8:
Correct: D — Caspases
Why: Caspases are the primary proteases that degrade the cytosol and cytoskeleton during apoptosis.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Cyclins
  • B — Lamins
  • C — Bcl-2

column1: Which specific protein is responsible for binding 'linker DNA' and assisting in the higher-order packing of nucleosomes?
column8:
Correct: A — Histone H1
Why: H1 is the linker histone that facilitates the condensation of beads-on-a-string into fibers.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Histone H3: H3 is part of the core octamer, not the linker.
  • C — Cohesin
  • D — Actin

column1: Which specific protein serves as the 'gatekeeper' of the nuclear pore complex, regulating the traffic of molecules between the nucleus and cytoplasm?
column8:
Correct: C — Nucleoporins
Why: Nucleoporins are the large protein assemblies that form the nuclear pore complex and regulate transport.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Histones
  • B — Lamins
  • D — Importins

column1: Which specific protein serves as the 'gatekeeper' of the nuclear pore complex, regulating the traffic of molecules between the nucleus and cytoplasm?
column8:
Correct: C — Nucleoporins
Why: Nucleoporins are the large protein assemblies that form the nuclear pore complex and regulate transport.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Histones
  • B — Lamins
  • D — Importins

column1: Regarding the S phase of the cell cycle, which of the following occurs simultaneously with DNA replication?
column8:
Correct: C — Synthesis of histones
Why: Histone production is tightly coupled with DNA replication during the S phase to package the new DNA.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Disassembly of the nuclear envelope
  • B — Alignment of chromosomes
  • D — Cytokinesis

column1: What is the structural significance of the 8-fold symmetry in the nuclear pore complex?
column2: It facilitates the binding of 8 different histone types.
column3: It corresponds to the 8 phases of mitosis.
column4: It allows for the simultaneous export of 8 mRNA strands.
column5: It provides a massive, organized framework for nucleoporins.
column8:
Correct: D — It provides a massive, organized framework for nucleoporins.
Why: The complex is a highly symmetric assembly of multiple nucleoporins that form the transport channel.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — It facilitates the binding of 8 different histone types.
  • B — It corresponds to the 8 phases of mitosis.
  • C — It allows for the simultaneous export of 8 mRNA strands.

column1: Which substage of Prophase I is characterized by the initiation of 'crossing-over' between non-sister chromatids?
column8:
Correct: C — Pachytene
Why: Pachytene is the specific stage where crossing-over (genetic recombination) takes place.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Zygotene
  • B — Diplotene
  • D — Leptotene

column1: In the 'EXCEPT' logic of MU-Varna, why would labeling chromatin as 'containing primarily RNA' be incorrect?
column2: Chromatin is primarily DNA and associated histones.
column3: Chromatin is made of lipids and proteins.
column4: Chromatin contains no RNA at all.
column5: RNA is only found in the cytoplasm.
column8:
Correct: A — Chromatin is primarily DNA and associated histones.
Why: The defining components of chromatin are DNA and histones; RNA is a secondary or transient component.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Chromatin is made of lipids and proteins.
  • C — Chromatin contains no RNA at all.: Chromatin does contain some nascent RNA, but it is primarily DNA and protein.
  • D — RNA is only found in the cytoplasm.

column1: What happens to the nuclear lamina during the transition from prophase to prometaphase?
column2: Lamins are phosphorylated, causing the lamina to disassemble.
column3: It thickens to protect the DNA.
column4: It detaches from the envelope and moves to the centrosomes.
column5: It converts into the contractile ring.
column8:
Correct: A — Lamins are phosphorylated, causing the lamina to disassemble.
Why: Phosphorylation by kinases leads to the breakdown of both the lamina and the envelope.
High-yield:
  • Heterochromatin: condensed, transcriptionally inactive, typically peripheral, attached to the nuclear lamina.
  • Euchromatin: open, transcriptionally active, lightly stained.
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — It thickens to protect the DNA.
  • C — It detaches from the envelope and moves to the centrosomes.: The lamina does not migrate; its subunits disperse into the cytosol.
  • D — It converts into the contractile ring.

column1: Which of the following describes the 'Fibrillar Center' of the nucleolus?
column2: Location of inactive DNA coding for rRNA.
column3: The protein meshwork supporting the nucleolus.
column5: The region where tRNA is processed.
column8:
Correct: A — Location of inactive DNA coding for rRNA.
Why: The fibrillar center contains the DNA templates for ribosomal RNA.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — The protein meshwork supporting the nucleolus.
  • C — Site of ribosomal subunit assembly.: This describes the granular component.
  • D — The region where tRNA is processed.

column1: During apoptosis, what role do the Bcl-2 family proteins play?
column4: They act as the primary executioner proteases.
column5: They regulate the release of pro-apoptotic factors from mitochondria.
column8:
Correct: D — They regulate the release of pro-apoptotic factors from mitochondria.
Why: Bcl-2 family members control mitochondrial membrane permeability.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — They trigger the inflammatory response.
  • B — They form the apoptotic bodies.
  • C — They act as the primary executioner proteases.

column1: A cell with a 'Barr Body' is most likely from which individual?
column8:
Correct: C — A healthy human female.
Why: One of the two X chromosomes in females is inactivated and condensed into a Barr body.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — A healthy human male.
  • B — A gamete (sperm or egg).
  • D — A cell undergoing necrosis.

column1: Which protein is the primary component of the 'Contractile Ring' during cytokinesis?
column8:
Correct: A — Actin
Why: The contractile ring is composed of actin filaments and myosin motor proteins.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Vimentin
  • C — Tubulin
  • D — Lamin B

column1: What is the fate of the nuclear envelope at the end of Telophase?
column2: It transforms into the cell membrane.
column4: It reforms around the individual chromosomes.
column5: It remains dispersed in the cytoplasm.
column8:
Correct: C — It reforms around the individual chromosomes.
Why: The nuclear envelope reassembles around the separated sets of chromosomes to form new nuclei.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — It transforms into the cell membrane.
  • B — It is permanently lost.
  • D — It remains dispersed in the cytoplasm.

column1: Which chromatin type is characterized by being 'transcriptionally active' and 'lightly stained'?
column8:
Correct: D — Euchromatin
Why: Euchromatin is dispersed, allowing access for transcription machinery.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Facultative heterochromatin
  • B — Nucleolar chromatin
  • C — Constitutive heterochromatin

column1: What distinguishes Necrosis from Apoptosis regarding the cell's physical size?
column5: Both involve the same size changes.
column8:
Correct: C — Apoptosis involves cell shrinkage.
Why: The cell condenses and shrinks during programmed cell death.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Apoptosis involves swelling.
  • B — Necrosis involves shrinkage.
  • D — Both involve the same size changes.

column1: The perinuclear space is the gap between:
column2: The inner and outer nuclear membranes.
column3: The nuclear pore and the RER.
column8:
Correct: A — The inner and outer nuclear membranes.
Why: The nuclear envelope consists of two membranes separated by this narrow space.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — The nuclear pore and the RER.
  • C — Chromatids during anaphase.
  • D — The nucleolus and the lamina.

column1: Which protein is part of the 'core' histone octamer?
column8:
Correct: A — H2A
Why: The octamer consists of two each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Lamin A
  • C — H1: H1 is the linker histone, located outside the octamer core.
  • D — Cohesin

column1: A mutation that prevents the formation of the 'synaptonemal complex' would directly affect which process?
column8:
Correct: C — Meiotic synapsis
Why: This complex is essential for pairing homologous chromosomes in Meiosis I.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Mitotic metaphase: Synaptonemal complexes are not formed in mitosis.
  • B — Nuclear pore assembly
  • D — Apoptosis

column1: Which nuclear structure is the site of rRNA synthesis and preliminary ribosomal assembly?
column8:
Correct: D — Nucleolus
Why: The nucleolus is a specialized region for manufacturing ribosome components.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Perinuclear space
  • B — Nuclear pore
  • C — Nuclear lamina

column1: In the MU-Varna exam, if an option states that the 'spindle is made of actin', why is it incorrect?
column2: The spindle is made of lamins.
column3: Actin is only found in the nucleus.
column4: The spindle is made of DNA.
column5: The spindle is composed of microtubules (tubulin).
column8:
Correct: D — The spindle is composed of microtubules (tubulin).
Why: Microtubules form the spindle fibers; actin forms the cytokinesis ring.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — The spindle is made of lamins.
  • B — Actin is only found in the nucleus.
  • C — The spindle is made of DNA.

column1: During which phase of mitosis do chromosomes align at the equatorial plate?
column8:
Correct: B — Metaphase
Why: Metaphase is defined by the alignment of chromosomes at the cell's center.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Prophase
  • C — Telophase
  • D — Anaphase

column1: What is 'nondisjunction' and when does it classically occur to cause chromosome abnormalities?
column2: The accidental fusion of two nuclei.
column3: Failure of chromosomes to separate during Meiosis I.
column4: Failure of DNA to replicate in S phase.
column5: The rupture of the nuclear envelope in G2.
column8:
Correct: B — Failure of chromosomes to separate during Meiosis I.
Why: Nondisjunction is the failure of separation, often in the first meiotic division.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — The accidental fusion of two nuclei.
  • C — Failure of DNA to replicate in S phase.
  • D — The rupture of the nuclear envelope in G2.

column1: Which of the following describes the 'Pars Granulosa' of the nucleolus?
column8:
Correct: B — Maturing ribosomal subunits.
Why: The granular part consists of nearly complete ribosomal subunits ready for export.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Lightly stained DNA.
  • C — Newly synthesized rRNA strands.: This is the 'pars fibrosa'.
  • D — The nuclear pore attachment site.

column1: What is the primary function of Histone H1?
column2: It forms the core of the nucleosome.
column3: It acts as a caspase during apoptosis.
column4: It synthesizes RNA in the nucleolus.
column5: It stabilizes the 30-nm chromatin fiber by pulling nucleosomes together.
column8:
Correct: D — It stabilizes the 30-nm chromatin fiber by pulling nucleosomes together.
Why: H1 is the 'linker' histone that helps fold nucleosomes into more compact structures.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — It forms the core of the nucleosome.
  • B — It acts as a caspase during apoptosis.
  • C — It synthesizes RNA in the nucleolus.

column1: Apoptosis during embryonic development is necessary for which of the following?
column8:
Correct: C — Digit separation (e.g., in the hands).
Why: The removal of 'webbing' between fingers is a classic example of programmed cell death.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Creation of the nuclear envelope.
  • B — Formation of the nucleolus.
  • D — Initiation of the S phase.

column1: Which structure connects the nucleus to the Rough ER?
column8:
Correct: D — Outer nuclear membrane.
Why: The outer membrane is physically continuous with the RER membrane.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Nuclear lamina.
  • B — Nucleolus.
  • C — Inner nuclear membrane.

column1: What happens to the DNA in a cell undergoing apoptosis according to a standard 'DNA ladder' test?
column2: It is randomly smeared across the gel.
column3: It is duplicated one last time.
column4: It is cleaved into regular fragments of about 180-200 base pairs.
column8:
Correct: C — It is cleaved into regular fragments of about 180-200 base pairs.
Why: Caspase-activated DNase cuts DNA between nucleosomes in an ordered pattern.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — It is randomly smeared across the gel.
  • B — It is duplicated one last time.
  • D — It remains intact and circular.

column1: Which of the following is NOT a feature of the nuclear lamina?
column4: Binds to heterochromatin at the nuclear periphery.
column5: Contains the genes for ribosomal RNA.
column8:
Correct: D — Contains the genes for ribosomal RNA.
Why: These genes are located in the nucleolus, not the lamina.
High-yield:
  • Heterochromatin: condensed, transcriptionally inactive, typically peripheral, attached to the nuclear lamina.
  • Euchromatin: open, transcriptionally active, lightly stained.
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Composed of intermediate filaments.
  • B — Supports the nuclear envelope structurally.
  • C — Binds to heterochromatin at the nuclear periphery.

column1: During Prophase I, when do homologous chromosomes align side-by-side (synapsis)?
column8:
Correct: C — Zygotene
Why: Zygotene is characterized by the 'zipping up' or synapsis of homologous pairs.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Anaphase I
  • B — Leptotene
  • D — Metaphase II: Metaphase II involves sister chromatids, not homologous synapsis.

column1: What defines the 'Prometaphase' stage in the context of the nuclear envelope?
column2: The envelope completely disassembles into small vesicles.
column5: The envelope becomes impermeable to all molecules.
column8:
Correct: A — The envelope completely disassembles into small vesicles.
Why: Prometaphase is marked by the final breakdown of the nuclear envelope.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — The envelope re-forms around chromosomes.: Re-formation occurs during telophase.
  • C — The envelope starts to thicken.
  • D — The envelope becomes impermeable to all molecules.

column1: In meiosis, the 'reductional' division refers to:
column8:
Correct: B — Meiosis I
Why: Meiosis I reduces the chromosome number from diploid (2n) to haploid (n).
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Cytokinesis
  • C — S phase
  • D — Meiosis II

column1: Which molecule is released from the mitochondria to trigger the formation of the apoptosome?
column8:
Correct: B — Cytochrome c
Why: The release of Cytochrome c into the cytosol is the 'point of no return' for apoptosis.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — DNA ligase
  • C — ATP
  • D — RNA polymerase

column1: A cell in G0 is described as:
column2: Exited the cell cycle and entered a quiescent state.
column8:
Correct: A — Exited the cell cycle and entered a quiescent state.
Why: Cells in G0 are metabolically active but have stopped dividing.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Replicating its DNA.
  • C — Undergoing rapid division.
  • D — Undergoing apoptosis.

column1: The 'nuclear pore complex' shows what type of rotational symmetry?
column8:
Correct: B — Eight-fold
Why: The NPC is composed of eight protein subunits arranged in a ring.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Two-fold
  • C — Circular (no symmetry)
  • D — Six-fold

column1: During apoptosis, cell 'blebbing' refers to:
column2: The formation of irregular bulges in the plasma membrane.
column5: The fusion of lysosomes with the nucleus.
column8:
Correct: A — The formation of irregular bulges in the plasma membrane.
Why: Blebbing is the protrusion of the membrane as the cytoskeleton breaks down.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — The swelling of the mitochondria.
  • C — The condensation of the nucleus.
  • D — The fusion of lysosomes with the nucleus.

column1: Which enzyme is responsible for the 'fragmentation' of DNA into nucleosomal units during apoptosis?
column8:
Correct: B — Endonuclease (CAD)
Why: Caspase-activated DNase (CAD) is the enzyme that cuts the DNA.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Proteasome
  • C — Helicase
  • D — DNA Polymerase

column1: Which of the following is true regarding the 'Inner Nuclear Membrane'?
column2: It is made of proteins only.
column3: It is continuous with the plasma membrane.
column4: It is associated with the nuclear lamina and heterochromatin.
column8:
Correct: C — It is associated with the nuclear lamina and heterochromatin.
Why: The inner membrane provides an anchor point for the lamina and peripheral DNA.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — It is made of proteins only.
  • B — It is continuous with the plasma membrane.
  • D — It is covered with ribosomes.

column1: A cell with highly active transcription would show:
column2: Extensive euchromatin and a large nucleolus.
column8:
Correct: A — Extensive euchromatin and a large nucleolus.
Why: Active cells need open DNA (euchromatin) and many ribosomes (large nucleolus).
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — A very small nucleus.
  • C — Large amounts of heterochromatin.
  • D — No nuclear pores.

column1: What is 'Pyknosis'?
column3: The breakdown of the plasma membrane.
column4: The condensation and shrinkage of the nucleus.
column5: The movement of chromosomes to the poles.
column8:
Correct: C — The condensation and shrinkage of the nucleus.
Why: Pyknosis is the hallmark nuclear condensation seen in both apoptosis and necrosis.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — The duplication of the nucleolus.
  • B — The breakdown of the plasma membrane.
  • D — The movement of chromosomes to the poles.

column1: In the cell cycle, checkpoints (like G1/S) are primarily regulated by:
column8:
Correct: D — Cyclins and Cyclin-Dependent Kinases (CDKs).
Why: The interaction of cyclins and CDKs controls the progression through checkpoints.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Histones and DNA.
  • B — The number of ribosomes.
  • C — The nuclear lamina.

column1: During Meiosis II, what is being separated?
column8:
Correct: A — Sister chromatids.
Why: Meiosis II is equational and separates the sisters, similar to mitosis.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Ribosomal subunits.
  • C — Homologous chromosomes.: These are separated in Meiosis I.
  • D — The nuclear membranes.

column1: Which of the following describes 'Karyolysis'?
column2: The dissolution or fading of the nucleus.
column8:
Correct: A — The dissolution or fading of the nucleus.
Why: Karyolysis is the complete loss of the nucleus due to DNA degradation.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Nuclear condensation.
  • C — The division of the cytoplasm.
  • D — The duplication of chromosomes.

column1: The 'Nucleolar Organizer Regions' (NORs) contain:
column3: Loops of DNA containing rRNA genes.
column8:
Correct: B — Loops of DNA containing rRNA genes.
Why: NORs are specific chromosomal locations that form the nucleolus.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Genes for mRNA.
  • C — Ribosomes ready for export.
  • D — Caspase-3 enzymes.

column1: In mitosis, when does the nucleolus disappear?
column8:
Correct: A — Prophase.
Why: The nucleolus disassembles early in mitosis as chromatin condenses.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Cytokinesis.
  • C — Anaphase.: It is long gone by the time chromosomes move.
  • D — G2 phase.

column1: Why does Necrosis cause inflammation but Apoptosis does not?
column4: Necrosis involves membrane rupture, spilling cellular contents.
column8:
Correct: C — Necrosis involves membrane rupture, spilling cellular contents.
Why: Released enzymes and debris from the ruptured cell trigger an immune response.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Necrosis is slower.
  • B — Apoptosis uses more energy.
  • D — Necrosis is programmed.

column1: Which of the following best describes 'Chiasmata'?
column2: The proteins holding the lamina together.
column3: Visible sites of crossing-over between homologous chromosomes.
column5: The pores in the nuclear envelope.
column8:
Correct: B — Visible sites of crossing-over between homologous chromosomes.
Why: Chiasmata are the X-shaped bridges seen in diplotene where exchange occurred.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — The proteins holding the lamina together.
  • C — The centers of the nucleolus.
  • D — The pores in the nuclear envelope.

column1: What is the primary role of 'Cohesins'?
column4: Holding sister chromatids together until anaphase.
column8:
Correct: C — Holding sister chromatids together until anaphase.
Why: Cohesin rings keep the identical copies paired for proper alignment.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Synthesizing DNA.
  • B — Degrading the nuclear lamina.
  • D — Packaging DNA into nucleosomes.

column1: The 'Haploid' (n) chromosome number is first reached at the end of which stage?
column8:
Correct: D — Meiosis I.
Why: After homologous chromosomes separate in Anaphase I, the daughter cells are haploid.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Fertilization.
  • B — S phase.
  • C — Mitosis.

column1: Which of these is a known trigger for the 'p53' protein to initiate apoptosis?
column8:
Correct: A — Irreparable DNA damage.
Why: p53 monitors DNA integrity and triggers death if the damage cannot be fixed.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Formation of a Barr body.
  • C — Excessive protein synthesis.
  • D — Entering the G0 phase.

column1: What is the function of the 'Satellite' DNA often found in constitutive heterochromatin?
column4: Provides structural stability to centromeres and telomeres.
column8:
Correct: C — Provides structural stability to centromeres and telomeres.
Why: Highly repetitive satellite DNA is crucial for chromosome structure and protection.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — Manufactures ribosomal subunits.: This happens in the nucleolus (rDNA).
  • B — Regulates the cell cycle directly.
  • D — Codes for cytoplasmic enzymes.

column1: If a question asks 'Where are ribosomes assembled?', the most precise nuclear answer is:
column4: The granular component of the nucleolus.
column8:
Correct: C — The granular component of the nucleolus.
Why: The 'Pars Granulosa' is the specific site of ribosomal subunit assembly.
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • A — The nucleoplasm.
  • B — The nuclear pore complex.
  • D — The outer nuclear membrane.

column1: Which of the following is an example of 'Facultative Heterochromatin'?
column2: The Barr body in female cells.
column8:
Correct: A — The Barr body in female cells.
Why: The Barr body is an X chromosome that is inactive in some cells but could be active in others (e.g., germ cells).
High-yield:
Why the other options are wrong / less precise:
  • B — Euchromatin.
  • C — Centromeres.
  • D — Telomeres.
